title: Monday, 16th September 2019

11:13 am
BE11:13am

We'll head into hedging policies and that kind of junk in a bit. First, the overview.

BE11:14am

(@andyalan10: as in, 0.25 of annual however it's valued. So, a PE of 10 is now worth a PE of 10.25 or 9.75)

Upaswellasdown Morning all.
Grouchmonkey Wasn't Ryanair getting pasted recently for hedging too much of its fuel costs?
BE11:15am

Here's SocGen.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Global oil prices are feeling the impact of the attack more intensely than those in the U.S., where the benchmark is slightly buffered by being delivered to a land-locked oil hub in Oklahoma. Brent's premium to West Texas Intermediate widened as much as 37% to $7.40 a barrel, the biggest gap since July.

BE11:15am

BE11:16am

The estimated 5.7 million barrels a day of lost Saudi production is the single biggest sudden disruption on record. It surpasses the loss of Kuwaiti and Iraqi supply during the Gulf War in August 1990, and the hit to Iranian output in 1979 from the Islamic Revolution, according to the International Energy Agency.

marktime And thank you for not trolling, can't find the words to express my disappointment with the grauniad so I won't try
11:16 am
BE11:16am

BE11:17am

[The whatever] are estimated to have disabled 5.7mbd of the country's oil production. This corresponds to 5.7% of the global oil market (of 100.1mbd in 2Q19), and 58% of Saudi August production of 9.75mbd - more than the swing producer has as spare capacity. Though the US has said it may release oil held in the SPR if needed (strategic petroleum reserve with 644mbbl), and Russia and others can also add some volumes, the reality is that the 5.7mbd disruption exceeds spare capacity available globally and that will likely drive a price spike. Most of the current 3.2mbd of OPEC (and world) spare capacity resides in Saudi Arabia (at around 2.3mbd). Even if the US eases sanctions on Iran (unlikely as the US has already blamed them for the attack), lifting Iranian sanctions would add no more than 2mbd. So markets are short - the only question is how long for.

BE11:17am

On the IEA's estimates, 2H 2019 world oil demand is projected at c.101.4mbd and non-OPEC supply at 65.4mbd. Thus to balance the market, production of OPEC crude and NGLs needs to be 36mbd - close to actual 2Q OPEC production of 35.6mbd. The loss of 5.7mbd of Saudi production is a massive shortfall versus oil demand. In our view, the real physical oil shortage and the risk premium necessary to price the fear/expectation of similar future attacks/shortages, will lead to a very material oil price spike to start with. A supply disruption will also raise short-term “precautionary” demand to hold oil in inventory, and so exaggerates the shortage - meaning that it does not matter that inventories are high in the short term. It is unknown how long repairs to the facilities will take while uncertainty, being no friend of the market, will also add to the perception of risk. We think Brent may spike to $75-80/bbl in the short term.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Energy and oil use per unit of real GDP in the West has been in a steady decline of course. However, the risk remains that a price spike may contribute to both softening GDP and oil demand in the new demand centres (East), and to politicians' renewed determination to speed up the energy transition away from fossil fuels. The oil majors will not suddenly abandon capital discipline, though they will benefit from the temporary margin and free cash flow expansion of a spike. But the higher the price goes, the harder it will fall. There are many precedents of previous supply shocks reviewed in brief on the next page. Historically, sharp disruptions and oil price spikes drive subsequent oil demand and GDP weakness. It is then just a question of the degree of a country's GDP sensitivity to oil prices (manufacturing versus service economies) as to how serious that economic impact is. The US is more balanced nowadays between its large consuming sector and a large shale liquids producing sector. But the main drivers of global oil demand growth in the East (China, Japan et al.) will suffer negative effects from higher oil prices.

marktime Quarter turn fasteners were made by Dzus for quick release of the battery box panels in an MGB
BE11:19am

Now, you'll be wanting some airline exposures right?

BE11:19am

Of course you do, that's why you're here rather than watching This Morning. Here's Credit Suisse.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

IAG and RYA most hedged for next 12 months: Following a 10% surge in the price of crude oil this morning (Brent at $66 at 8am UK time), we highlight the exposure of the European airlines. IAG and Ryanair have most hedging cover at c.70% for the next 12 months, compared to Air France-KLM at only c.50% per latest disclosure.

#REF! morning, in honour of the oil news i am listening to Drones by Rise Against
hornblower if you get bored with oil any grey on MJ Gleeson results would be appreciated
BE11:20am

Margins key to earnings resilience – IAG least vulnerable, Air France-KLM most exposed: However, the key to understand fuel price exposure lies in margins, with the highest margin businesses best equipped to absorb fuel price increases, given (all else equal) a fuel bill increase should represent a lower proportion of earnings for higher margin players. As such, IAG has least exposure with our analysis of the sensitivity of substituting a $700/mt unhedged market fuel price for the $650/mt assumption we currently use, suggesting a 5% risk to IAG 2020E EBIT. This compares to a c.21% risk to Air France-KLM 2020E EBIT given its lowest-in-class margins, again illustrating the risks to AF-KL’s investment case as it prepares to announce a strategy update while unit revenues soften.

BE11:20am

Potential for further capacity tightening: It remains to be seen how oil pricing will settle. However, following moves across the sector to limit capacity growth into 2020 given demand uncertainties, higher fuel pricing may prompt more capacity tightening for winter.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

BE11:21am

Or if you want a second opinion, Caz.

BE11:22am

The table below shows the sensitivity of our EPS estimates to a 10% change in fuel prices, all other things being unchanged. In reality, air fares almost always go up in response to higher fuel prices so the impact on EPS will be more muted than the table shows. The table clearly shows that the low cost carriers (LCCs) are more impacted by a change in the fuel price than IAG. This is because fuel represents a higher percentage of the total cost base of an LCC, since an LCC’s other costs (eg. labour, airport fees etc) are lower than those of a full service carrier.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

BE11:23am

Open the image in a new tab if it's illegible.

undefined
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Best mention the explorers, who (to state the obvious) have the highest leverage to these sorts of supply shocks.

Tullow also has drill results

BE11:25am

And an Investec upgrade, which we'll get to momentarily, but first the sector read.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Here's Numis.

VV75 morning
BE11:26am

● A US$10/bbl increase in Brent oil prices from US$60-70/bbl would see our discovered resource NAV rise 43% for Tullow, but 49% for PetroTal and 96% for Lekoil; the median change is ~40%.
● Moving further up the oil price scale, increasing LT oil prices from US$70-80/bbl sees our discovered resource NAV rise 29% for Tullow, but 32% for PetroTal and 51% for Lekoil; the median change is ~25%.
● Oil prices rose 10% this morning in Asia trading on the back of the drone attack in Saudi Arabia on Saturday that has caused 5.7mmb/d of oil production to be shut-in (i.e. around 60% of Saudi’s oil production and 5% of global oil products consumption).

BE11:26am

Analyst is Thomas Martin.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

● The demonstration of the vulnerability of the world’s largest oil exporter is a wake-up call for oil markets and we believe argues for structurally higher risk premium to be reflected in the commodity price.
● Details of the actual damage caused is lacking and current repair time estimates range anywhere from days to months. If its days or even 2-3 weeks this is not a major supply problem for the world - Saudi has 185mmbbls in storage at its loading ports and this equates to 32 days of the lost production (of course this ignores the now more credible risk of successful drone attacks being launched against the storage tanks and/or associated export infrastructure).

chomsky hello
DRichi Speaking of Explorers- I've been invested in President Energy for years and can confirm that the oil price rise today has had no impact whatsoever on it's shareprice. Que sera...
BE11:27am

If Iran was not subject to an oil embargo it could instantly fill almost half the lost production gap, but seeing as how it has already been blamed by the US for the attacks, this is not likely to be allowed. The greater risk is that proof emerges that Iran did in fact directly orchestrate the attacks and this causes an escalation of conflict in the region - we have already seen how vulnerable oil tankers and now Saudi infrastructure is to relatively unsophisticated attacks over the last few months.
● President Trump has authorised the release of oil from the US Strategic Petroleum Reserve to ensure markets remain well supplied, but also says the US is 'locked and loaded' to respond, pending discussions with Saudi Arabia over how to proceed.

BE11:28am

Cloudcuckoo Anyone know if Man group (or other CTAs) are long/short oil. A big move like this could be impactful...
11:29 am
BE11:29am

And here's that Investec Tullow upgrade as part of a sector note, which goes for 62 pages and was out of date approximately three seconds after being published.

BE11:29am

All is not lost at $60 Brent! In fact, sector fundamentals remain robust with the sector arguably operationally leaner than ever before, generating significant FCF and distributing dividends. Tullow’s discovery in Guyana has shown that transformational discoveries can still be made and valuations remain attractive with the sector generally still trading at an average c.20% discount to RENAV. As a result we maintain our constructive bias. However headwinds remain. Investors remain wary of the volatile oil price, while the general negative sentiment towards oil stocks is still present.

BE11:30am

ector fundamentals still robust - The majority of balance sheets across our coverage have now recovered, to the extent that they can now survive a $40-50/bbl world. FCF generation remains broadly positive and significant across the sector, with margins wide and they continue to operate in a low cost environment. Importantly E&P companies are distributing dividends again, an important step for shareholders, as it begins to demonstrate the sector’s confidence in the sustainability of its FCF profiles. Valuations remain undemanding. The sector continues to trade at an average c.20% discount to our RENAV’s. We expect to see multiple transformational catalysts in the sector in H2, with asset sales, farm-downs, FID’s, project start-ups and high impact exploration set to move the needle. These events could be the catalyst the sector needs to finally re-rate.

marktime alfa fin continue to disappoint
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Upgrades and downgrades: We upgrade Tullow Oil to Buy. In our view, Guyana success has already materially changed the outlook for the company and there is still potential upside. We expect the company to monetise part of its stake in country and this could be the catalyst to finally solve the balance sheet issue that still lingers in the background. We downgrade SOCO to Sell, as we see the company stuck in limbo. The company’s FCF outlook is limited and our concern is that future growth requires significant spend to convert 2C resources into 2P reserves. This in our view puts the dividend that underpins the stock at risk

BE11:30am

High conviction in... Premier (TP 110p), Seplat (TP 205p), Tullow (TP 250p). Premier remains well positioned to delever through 2019/20 and the potential sale of its Zama asset could be the catalyst for a re-rating that has long been on the horizon. Seplat is now investing in long term growth and we see significant FCF generation beyond 2020 and the scope for rising shareholder distributions, which continues to underpin our constructive thesis. Tullow’s potential basin opening exploration success in Guyana can pave a new path for the company and a potential farm-down could finally fix its lingering balance sheet issue.

BE11:31am

And finally! Joe.

chomsky Is anyone concerned about the long term impact? higher oil prices could lead to increasing fuel prices. This would put more pressure on a global economy that is already coping with a slowing manufacturing sector and stubbornly low growth.
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Number 2 out of 2 for Eco Atlantic and partners on the Orinduik block offshore Guyana.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Morning folks.
VV75 LVMH taking a bath on chatter of tariffs on luxury goods, any read through for Burberry available?
BE11:32am

Here's Berenberg to talk us through that, at which point we can hopefully move on.

BE11:33am

The partners have not provided a resource estimate for the new discovery, although we note that a competent person’s report (CPR) by Gustavson Associates from Eco Atlantic had estimated a gross recoverable resource (P50) of 148mboe. The partners are evaluating additional thinner sands above and below the main pay for possible incremental pay. While a gross oil column of 14m is not big and compares with 55m at Jethro, we note that the aerial extent of Joe was also significantly larger than Jethro based on the CPR. We therefore add Joe as a 100 mboe prospect to our NAV, risked at 50%.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

We assume Jethro is a 250mboe discovery, making it large enough for a standalone commercial development. In this scenario, smaller discoveries can be used as tie-back developments, lowering commerciality threshold.

K H Developed Europe Airline peers by NI margins please?
BE11:33am

The partners will now focus on assessing full results of the two exploration wells, as well as on understanding resource upside from the extension of Exxon’s Hammerhead discovery onto Orinduik before selecting the next prospect to be drilled in 2020. We expect more colour on recoverable resource potential of the two discoveries.

FJ Airbus weak today?
BE11:34am

We expect Tullow to farm out part of its 60% interest in the Orinduik ahead of a commercial development in order to optimise capital allocation. We estimate that selling half of its stake could raise c$1bn, a substantial amount relative to its net debt of $2.9bn. We note that Qatar Petroleum could be a potential buyer after its recent farm-in to the block.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Our price target implies 2019E/20E EV/EBITDAX of 5.5x/5.0x. We believe a premium valuation is justified due to potential sell-down of Tullow’s stake in the Orinduik block.

cracklenpop Any grey on SJP following more weekend revelations about its 'cufflinks and cruises' culture?
undefined
BE11:35am

And so, to other stuff.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Airbus, mentioned, is a tariff story.

BE11:36am

BE11:37am

Giving the latest on the fight between Airbus and Boeing over alleged subsidies by their respective governments

madrugada BeE: didn’t Soco get an upgrade last week to 120p?
11:37 am
BE11:37am

https://www.politi...-subsidies-1496170

BE11:38am

Gist is that the US gains the right to impose “punitive tariffs” on EU products “from cheeses to Airbus planes and parts.”

BE11:38am

Now, how much of this is new? Not a whole lot, according to JPM.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

It is not new news that the WTO has ruled against AIR; the only new news here is the reported issuance of the confidential letters. Clearly the headlines are not helpful for AIR and the shares are down c3% at the time of writing (which may also be partly due to the oil price spike). However, the WTO situation is complex and nuanced ...

BE11:39am

The WTO still needs to rule on Boeing’s alleged subsidies: AIR has filed a counter-claim with the WTO arguing Boeing also received large subsidies from the US government. This case is running about 6-9 months behind the case against AIR.

BE11:39am

The US might have more to lose from an aircraft tariff war: (1) Boeing sells more aircraft to Europe than Airbus sells to US. Excluding lessors, from 2014-2018 c12% of AIR’s total deliveries were to the US. Over the same five year period c15.6% of Boeing’s deliveries were to Europe. Also, most of AIR’s deliveries to US airlines are lower value narrow body aircraft. Boeing’s deliveries to Europe include both narrow bodies and higher value wide body aircraft. (2) AIR has a final assembly line in US (which may help it to avoid some tariffs) but Boeing doesn’t have a final assembly line one in Europe

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Course, the conspiracy theory here is that Airbus gets beaten up while Boeing tries to get the Max back in the air.

BE11:41am

A conspiracy theory JPM is willing to entertain.

BE11:41am

First, many airlines around the world have been
impacted financially and operationally by the MAX delays and they are clearly not happy about this. A tariff war that drives up the price of aircraft in Europe and the US (assuming EU retaliation) would surely anger the airlines affected and we wonder if Boeing wants to add further stress to its relations with its airline customers. Second, Boeing needs the EU to approve the return to service of the MAX. Whilst regulatory/safety issues should be completely separate to the WTO debate we wonder if this will really be the case in the cut-and-thrust of complex international negotiations.

11:42 am

Amigo Holdings PLC (AMGO:LSE): Last: 74.90, up 1.2 (+1.63%), High: 77.10, Low: 74.00, Volume: 141.19k
Provident Financial PLC (PFG:LSE): Last: 421.80, down 7 (-1.63%), High: 427.40, Low: 419.90, Volume: 77.09k
11:52 am
HomeServe PLC (HSV:LSE): Last: 1,151, down 20 (-1.71%), High: 1,194, Low: 1,148, Volume: 77.38k
BE11:53am

Have Peel Hunt.

BE11:53am

In reality, not much was new by way of criticism: a focus on the early withdrawal charge, comments around the overseas trips, and a supposed demand by many partners for a “culture shift”. There are also other comments about the fact that sales staff can earn bonuses and receive payments for working at home (in reality reflects the costs of the offices that SJP maintain otherwise). The SJP response was that a review of the strategy will include a look at rewards and recognition. The reality remains that SJP charges are not out of line with the rest of the industry and there has already been a shift towards trying to balance growth with quality advice (referred to in passing by the article). SJP is currently trading at a 17% discount to reported EEV net asset value.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

And Numis, on contingent charges.

hornblower SJP CEO referring to the cruises as holidays when the tax treatment is business meetings. HMRC might be interested in that
BE11:54am

We note that a new concern for some investors is SJP’s exposure to the proposed FCA ban on contingent charges for DB to DC pension transfers. We believe that this concern is mostly because the company has declined to disclose its current exposure to DB to DC transfers (not unreasonable in our view given there is a regulatory review ongoing and the activity is only a subset of one segment of its business) and therefore represents a difficult to quantify risk for investors. We attempt to quantify SJP’s exposure and conclude that the worst case potential exposure is likely to be relatively modest and and therefore not something that investors should worry too much about from a big picture perspective.

BE11:54am

Assuming a worst case of: a full ban being implemented, SJP not being able to offset this in any way (e.g. by introducing non-contingent charging) and the advisers not being able to re-deploy their time currently spent on DB to DC into something else productive, we estimate c.3% of short-medium term cash profits could be at risk. We estimate that the full value impact would be c.8% of the market cap, also taking into account the longer term cash flows. We note however that the share price (-12% off the peak) has probably already captured some/all of this worst case value decline.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

But probably not touching the back book so no big whoop.

hagilon Bets on Brexit, will there be a second referendum?
BE11:55am

Whilst a ban would likely be negative for SJP at the margin, we do not believe that it would be that material and therefore not something which investors should be unduly concerned about. Retail financial services is, quite rightly in our view, a highly regulated industry and one where consumer trust of providers is essential to a well-functioning market. This is not the first piece of (potential) new regulation and it will almost certainly not be the last. We note that SJP has successfully navigated numerous regulatory and other industry changes over its lifetime and would hope/expect this to be no different. Regulation does not fundamentally change the industry's primary social purpose (and indeed the structural growth investment case for shareholders) which is to help individuals save for their future financial needs.

undefined
chomsky 6/4 for another referendum before 2020 with ladbrokes
11:56 am
BE11:56am

I can only assume comments are broken because we've got requests for China Take and Brexit.

2s10s @haglion: depends on a new development emerging about whether Boris will prorogue parliament for a SECOND time. If parliament sits then there is momentum for rebel MPs to amend any legislation going through.
2s10s @BE: haha, it wasn't a formal request for China grey. Just pitching in like. y' know.
hagilon I have the same opinion
BE11:58am

Want Goldman's latest "we put a 30% probability on this outcome" type filler?

BE11:58am

Course you do.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

We maintain the base case that the UK will leave the EU with a deal by the end of October, but the UK and EU agreeing to another Article 50 extension paving the way for second referendum or pre-Brexit general election is also a plausible alternative scenario. Investigating the macro economic implications of each potential path, in our “deal scenario” a quarter of the cumulative GDP shortfall associated with the Brexit vote is reversed by end-2020. However, in our “delay” scenario, an escalation of uncertainty will prolong one of the weakest phases of UK GDP growth ever recorded outside a recession.

BE12:00pm

And Morgan Stanley.

BE12:00pm

With the way forward on Brexit and the outlook likely to become clearer soon, we expect the MPC to stay on hold. Changes since August likely modestly reinforce the MPC's weak hawkish bias. Waiting to see which side of the Brexit fork is taken: We expect an extension to the Brexit date, and 4Q UK elections to decide the way forward. We see the outcome as almost evenly balanced between an orderly resolution – remain or a deal – of Brexit (55% probability) which would lead to a rebound in growth and the MPC hiking in 2H20, we think, and a no-deal Brexit (45% probability) which would hit growth and lead to 50bp of cuts and a relaunch of TFS, in our view. Given the likelihood of greater clarity on the way forward in the relatively near future, we think that the hurdle to any change in the MPC position is high. No recession yet, though still subpar: In line with the MPC's August forecast, 3Q growth so far is coming in significantly better after 2Q's 0.2%Q contraction, and the economy looks likely to avoid a recession. July growth was 0.3%M, pushing up the smoothed 3M/3M measure to zero, employment growth continues, and pay growth holding at a cycle high should support the consumer. Moreover, we expect some support from reduced summer maintenance in the car industry and some stockpiling ahead of the end-October scheduled Brexit date. That said, weak PMIs and other data point to growth holding below trend. Upward pressures: Weaker GBP, a tighter labour market, easier fiscal policy and the surge in PPI claims point to upward pressures on inflation since the August meeting. In particular, the tight labour market has helped to push pay growth to a cycle high (total pay 4% 3M/Y), pointing to unit labour costs rising at around 3%, above a level consistent with the 2% inflation target. Furthermore, the spending review increased spending by 0.6% of GDP from next March, which is likely to add 0.2-0.3pp to MPC growth forecasts. Also, the surge in PPI compensation claims ahead of the August 29 deadline – at least £4bn, judging by the increase in bank provisions – should boost near-term payouts and consumption. Sticking to a modest hawkish bias: With inflation above target, an economy at full employment and policy rates (0.75%) well below the MPC's estimate of neutral (2-3%), we see the MPC's hawkish bias as likely to continue. In fact, with upwards pressure on inflation, and a tick-up in inflation expectations, the tone may get slightly more hawkish, although we are sceptical of any meaningful change to guidance before the way forward on Brexit is clearer. MPCometer: A neutral MPC, waiting for more clarity on Brexit

12:05 pm

@Hornblower: absolutely not!

MJ Gleeson PLC (GLE:LSE): Last: 840.00, down 10 (-1.18%), High: 852.00, Low: 822.00, Volume: 24.02k
BE12:06pm

And the fact that I've not even read its numbers this morning won't stop me cutting and pasting Cannacord, which I assume has.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

As guided in the recent trading update, the Group has delivered a good, solid strong set of full year results, a smidgen ahead of our forecasts. As expected, the results were driven by a strong increase in completions (+25%) with margins moving lower. Recent trading and demand for its affordable product remains very strong. Given the strong demand, revenue and margins (pricing should be good and accommodating) should remain supportive of consensus in FY2020. The market may be a bit disappointed with the news that Strategic Land is not being sold as there will now not be an opportunity for more significant capital returns using the sales proceeds; Strategic Land remains a profitable and cash generative business which is complementary to Homes. The balance sheet remains very strong and the Group is in the sweet spot of the residential market for which demand remains very buoyant. We would not expect any material changes to consensus for FY2020; it looks well underpinned with the targeted 2,000 units for 2022 looking achievable by 2021. Shares have been the strongest performer in the sector YTD and now reside on a 2020E valuation that looks well supported but arguably close to fair value.

BE12:06pm

The Group has delivered a strong set of results as expected with PBT a smidgen ahead of our forecast of £41.0m at £41.2m. Key points include:

Revenue increased by c.+27% to £249.9m with a +11% increase in PBT to £41.2m; PBT was higher than our forecast of c.£41.0m.
EPS grew by +10% to 61.0p with the DPS as expected at 34.5p (+8%).
Homes saw a strong increase in completions, up by +25% to 1,529 at an ASP of £128.9k (+3%). Operating margins edged back to 15.3% from 17.0% as build rates increased and overheads moved up.
Strategic Land delivered a good performance with operating profits increasing to £13.0m from £12.6m as the Group made 9 land sales.
Net cash was £30.3m at the end of December 2018, as expected.
Demand remains robust with no signs of customer caution in their markets, despite Brexit issues.
Outlook comments point to a continued good backdrop with demand remaining strong. Management is confident that it will see another "excellent" year in FY2020.
It was also announced that the Board has decided to keep Strategic Land and not sell it, after a strategic review.
The search for a permanent CEO continues with external and internal candidates being seen - we would be surprised if the experienced and well regarded current interim CEO did not get the job.

BE12:06pm

Shares trade on a FY2020E price-to-book multiple of around 2.0 times with a dividend yield of c.4.5%. Valuation looks well supported but arguably up with events after a strong c.+30% YTD share price bounce.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

And Liberum, briefer, and shop.

BE12:07pm

MJ Gleeson has announced 11% growth in PBT, 1% better than we expected. Homes operating profit grew 15%, lagging Homes volume growth of 25%, due to a well flagged and expected drop in margin as it becomes more expensive to build at faster rates in support of strong demand. Homes remains on track to double volumes by 2022, but might achieve this eighteen months early. Strategic Land will be retained, and its strong pipeline suggests sustainable profits and cash flows. We see over 10% TSR upside to our raised target price of 909p, based on a sum-of-the-parts valuation that values Homes as a growing small company rather than a housebuilder reflecting the limited competition and superior growth enjoyed by Gleeson Homes. Competition is still limited in Homes’ target market and demand remains strong.
